I'm disappointed at recent posts by "influencers" bragging about firing employees - especially new ones - as if it is a badge of honor, a symbol of their great decisiveness.

One bragged about firing someone after one day. Another about firing his best designer because she failed him in a client meeting -- even though he admittedly gave literally zero guidance and support to the designer.
You sourced them. You interviewed them. You deemed them a great fit and hired them. You onboarded them. You set their course. You were accountable to provide support and guidance.
But now it is all their fault that it didn't work out?
We are supposed to believe that the same insufficient discernment you used to choose them can be trusted to evaluate their future in just 8 hours of employment?
Or that firing your most talented employee, after giving them zero support, shows great leadership?
Sure, we all make bad hires. We all have employees which don't work out.

But the firing - except for ethical and behavioral issues - should never be thought of as anything other than a regrettable scenario which demands compassion for the employee and learning and growth by the employer.
